docs.title: ISO-15118 Check Digit
docs.text:
In the e-mobility space, a Contract Identifier (short: CID; also known as eMA-ID or EVCO-ID) is a unique identifier that relates to a contract between a EMSP and EV driver. The format of the CID is the following:

┌──────────────┬───┬──────────┬───┬─────────┬──────────┬───┬─────────────┐
│<country-code>│<s>│<party-id>│<s>│<id-type>│<instance>│<s>│<check-digit>│
├──────────────┼───┼──────────┼───┼─────────┼──────────┼───┼─────────────┤
│      2       │ 1 │    3     │ 1 │    2    │     8    │ 1 │      1      │
└──────────────┴───┴──────────┴───┴─────────┴──────────┴───┴─────────────┘

Individual parts: * <country-code>: A contract was signed under the law of this country. * <s>: Separator. Typically it's a hyphen ("-"). * <provider-id>: The company with which the contract exists, unique per country. * <id-type>: Type of identifier. For CID it's value is "C", for EVSE it's "E". * <instance>: Uniquely references a customer account at the provider. * <check-digit>: An optional checksum digit to validate the CID.

Since the CID is often exchanged between humans, it's important to have a checksum digit to detect typing errors. The ISO-15118 standard defines a checksum algorithm for the check digit.
